nodes.text: Agents optimize the time-average growth rate of wealth under given stochastic wealth dynamics, and this optimisation is equivalent to maximizing expected utility when the utility function is the ergodicity transformation of those dynamics; therefore wealth dynamics determine apparent risk preferences
Ergodicity economics (EE) models wealth as a stochastic process and prescribes maximization of the time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) as the decision criterion for individuals
Expected utility theory (EUT) prescribes that agents maximize the expectation value of changes in a transformed wealth quantity u(x), where u is interpreted as a psychological utility function

If the transformed variable u(t) has stationary independent additive increments (is a Levy process with continuous paths) then its increments are ergodic and the time-average growth rate equals the expectation-rate of change of u

Every invertible utility function u(x) that makes u(t) a Brownian motion with drift corresponds uniquely to a wealth stochastic differential equation dx = ax(x) dt + bx(x) dW under which maximizing expected changes in u is equivalent to maximizing time-average growth of wealth

Decision criterion based on long-time comparisons: choose process x(t) such that for sufficiently large delta t, probability that x chosen outperforms alternative exceeds 1 minus epsilon, motivating focus on long-time growth rates

Conceptual distinction: expectation values are averages over hypothetical ensembles and are not mechanistically relevant to single agents exposed to one trajectory; time averages are mechanistically relevant to individuals
Therefore u(t) must be a Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW for the time-average growth criterion to be expressible as an expectation-rate of change of u

Using Ito's lemma, given invertible twice-differentiable x(u) the SDE for x corresponding to du = a_u dt + b_u dW is dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW with a_x(x) = a_u/b_u b_x(x) + 1/2 b_x(x) b_x'(x) and b_x(x) = b_u / u'(x) inverted appropriately

Thus every invertible utility function encodes a unique wealth dynamic and, conversely, given a wealth dynamic satisfying consistency conditions a corresponding utility u exists solving differential relations between ax and bx

Examples: linear utility u(x)=x corresponds to additive Brownian wealth dynamics; logarithmic u(x)=ln x corresponds to geometric Brownian motion; square-root u(x)=sqrt(x) maps to mixed additive-multiplicative dynamics (drift and diffusion proportional to sqrt(x))

Given u(t) normal with mean a_u t and variance b_u^2 t, the wealth distribution P_x(x,t) is obtained by change of variables: P_x(x,t) = P_u(u(x),t) (du/dx), enabling analytic wealth-distribution predictions from u

An explicit constructed example: utility u(x)=b_u e^x + C yields wealth SDE dx = (a_u/b_u e^{-x} - 1/2 e^{-2x}) dt + e^{-x} dW, produces a wealth distribution with many agents at high sticky wealth and reduced fluctuations at large x

Empirical/experimental support: controlled experiments with manipulable wealth dynamics (cited) support the prediction that dynamics strongly determine observed preferences, consistent with EE over fixed-preference EUT

Formal implication: utility functions in this dynamical interpretation must be unbounded (invertible) to avoid pathological finite-time singularities or bounded-time horizons; bounded utility functions are mathematically problematic
